item.description: In Bikuben (The bee hive), players control a bee that starts in the center of a hexagonal hive and moves outwards by throwing two dice with six colors. The moves must correspond to the colors on the dice. When arriving the fields outside the hive, the bee collects pollen and starts over again.

The game has 60 cards consisting of the head, the body and two feet of "Betty Spaghetty and her friends".

Players take turns to combine the cards in funny ways (but the feet must match!). The person to complete one figure keeps it.

The person with the most figures when the cards run out is the winner.

Spillet om Askepott (The Cinderella Game) is a children's game where the players compete to become Cinderella. They have the following tasks to fulfill:


 Find the Fairy Godmother to transform to a princess
 Move to the ball
 Find the watch to transform back
 Try the lost shoe
 Move to the castle again and marry the prince

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
ALF'a beta is a versatile card game consisting of four decks of all letters of the alphabet (including the Norwegian letters Æ, Ø, Å, and the German letters Ä, Ö and Ü), and one joker (the "ALF") in each deck.

The rules describe many variants on how to play, including learning children how to spell, enriching the vocabulary of older players, making crosswords to challenge the other players, a regular game, "The Pyramid", and two solitaire versions.

Gøy med klokken (Fun with the clock) is an educational children's game where the players learn to tell the time.

The game has 24 tiles with times of the day, and the players must correctly adjust the hands of the clock on the board according to these tiles.
Based on the "Moomin" characters of the Finnish writer Tove Jansson, the players of this game searches in the garden of the Moomins to find the lost hats of Moominpappa.

Newtonspillet is a spin-off from "Newton", a science program from the official Norwegian Broadcasting (NRK) aimed for youth.

Players move around the board and answers science questions from the following four categories: "Sea and Water", "Land", "Air and Sky" and "The Universe".
Each turn, the players get a topic and must take turns to name an object of that class (flowers, countries, Norwegian animals etc).

Pelle Politibil: Trafikkspillet is a Norwegian children's game where each player controls "Pelle politibil" (a police car from a children's television show).

When playing this game, children learn traffic signs and rules.

Sim Serim is an abstract game designed for two players (or two teams consisting of two players each).

This game by Heinrich Glumpler is played on a square wooden board with 7×7 fields where the fields in two corners are replaced by icons representing the players ("moon" and "sun"). The players sit at the corner of the board showing their respective icon.

The game is played in rounds. At the start of each round players reveal 1 to 4 stones of their color simultaneously. The number of revealed stones decides the order in which both players place their stones on the board.

The player do not have a lot of choice when placing their stones since new stones must be placed in the current row - meaning: the row where the last stone was placed in the previous round. Only after the current row is filled completely the active player may select a new row by placing a stone at the edge of the board.

It is much more important to foresee the order in which stones are placed since the resulting patterns on the board will decide the number of points each player gets at the end of the game.

The special flavour of the game results from the fact, that the scoring takes place in the vertical and horizontal lines of the board - running in a 45 degree angle to the rows where the stones were placed.

Players earn points for each magic wand, meaning each combination of exactly three stones lying in line and adjacent to each other. The tricky part is, that a player will lose points for any magic wand that is too long - having more than three stones.

A spin-off from the Norwegian TV-channel TV2's game show "Klisterhjerne".

The trivia questions are taken from the Norwegian elementary, middle and high school curriculum, and each players gets questions depending on their age. There are multiple choice and true/false questions.

Based on the characters of the popular Norwegian song-writer and musician Alf Prøysen.

The players play the animals starting at "Dyreskolen" (Animal's school), where Miss Crow is teacher. They are looking for different items that they need at the school, but when someone finds the school bell, the school starts and they need to hurry to the school.

name.value: Se og Hør: Det store kjendisspillet 2007

item.description:
As paparazzi photographer, you are hunting for the best pictures of famous and/or royal people.
You get points if you can guess who is hiding behind the mustache, hat or sunglasses, and if you can answer questions about them.

A follow-up to Se og HÃ¸r: Det store sladderspil with updated photographs.

link.value: Se og Hør: Det store sladderspil

item.description: A word game where the players collect letters to make as long words as possible. It is even possible get imaginary words approved by the other players if you can explain them and find a reasonable meaning.
Plays just like regular Lotto, except the tiles depicts an amount and the boards have simple math questions.

Based on Disney's Aladdin, the players compete to carry Aladdin's lamp to the Sultan's castle. But before the castle opens, they player's must match the cards on his/her hand with the cards laid out on the board.

A spinner decides if a player moves this turn, or if he/she is attacked by the evil Jafar.

name.value: Moro å lære: Vi legger sammen

item.description:
The players learn how to add numbers from one to six. The players collect colored chips.

When the player believes he or she has collected the correct number of chips, the calculation is turn around and the correct answer is revealed.

The best adder wins.

A team playing game where each turn, one team member gets an item to mime, sing or makes a sound of. If the rest of the team correctly guesses the item, they place a pawn on the board.

The first team to get four-in-a-row wins.

Also released in a travel edition.

In October 1960, The Andy Griffith Show made its television debut—and, to the delight of millions worldwide, the show has been on the air ever since! Young and old alike love Mayberry’s cast of characters, timeless humor and the values the show promotes.

Mayberry-Opoly is a game celebrating this classic television show. Players buy favorite Mayberry properties, then increase their property value by collecting Bait Shops and trading them for a Big Fish. Who knows, you may win a blue ribbon for your homemade pickles, sell some jars of Miracle Salve, find your windows broken by Ernest T. Bass, or get arrested by Deputy Barney Fife!

Whether you are relaxing at the fishin’ hole or planning your escape from cell #2, Mayberry-Opoly is loaded with twists that will have everyone laughing and reminiscing about America’s favorite small town.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
In this two-player game, each player runs a chain of fast-food joints: one specializes in burgers and the other in pizzas. As each expands, he takes on some of the menu items of the other in order to compete for customers. Later, each can open family restaurants and even high-class dining establishments. The most successful chain will win in the end!

Players alternate turns as the active player. Each turn consists of five actions.
1. Production. Where a player draws cubes from a bag (Here the cubes represent different resources.)
2. Players trade and use special abilities to convert cubes into more helpful combinations.
3. Spend their resources to build up their fast food empire (by improving their restaurants to diners or by increasing their publicity)
4. Calculating their current score – first player to 12 victory points wins.
5. Discard unused and excess goods in preparation to start the next round.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
From the box: Collect the most slices to form scrumptious layer cakes. A game for 2-4 players : Ages 5 & Up.

Contents: 52 Unique triangular shaped "cake slice" cards and 8 missing slice cards. Rules for two games Take the Cake and Piece of Cake.

French and English Rule booklet

Players play cake slice cards from their hand to start and/or complete full cakes (6 slices). The player with the most complete cakes at the end of the game wins.

name.value: The Rocky Mountain National Park Game: Tricky Trails

item.description:
This is a small roll and move game with multiple paths through Rocky Mountain National Park; first person to exit the park wins.

Special spaces on the board cause players to draw from either an event deck (moving their piece or causing lost turns), or from a "Tricky Trail" deck, which consists of three levels of trivia questions (Easy, Moderate, and Strenuous) which can give various levels of bonuses for a correct answer.

The game comes with a Rocky Mountain map gameboard, printed on a thin green cloth. The player pawns are detailed miniature animals; a mountain lion, Fox, Bear, and Long Horn Sheep.

Scores of Bridge variants for fewer than four players have been invented, most of them for two players. The few games created for a threesome vainly searching for a fourth tend to be unexciting and overly dependent on luck. This is an attempt to fill the breach. Game play is very much like the parent game, although some changes in the scoring rules have been made. The major twist: the players who win the bidding must play defense—and they still have to take a majority of the tricks!

This is a travel game that teaches players to receognize license plates for "the 48 States and District of Columbia." Players travel the "lower 48" collecting license plates when passing through the capitol city of a state, each of which may only be visited once per game. The license plates have varying point values depending on the difficulty in reaching the state. A die roll of six requires the player to draw a "Detour" card which alters the players movement in various ways. When all license plates have been claimed, players add up their scores to determine the winner.

(From the publisher's site)

A game of bidding to discover the world of chicory while building up a commercial empire !

Easy to understand, you have to win all the cards that make up the chicory chain : from the purchasing of the first seeds, to the roasting process, and then the marketing of your chicory product.
Compelling, chance alone cannot help you to see your project through. Bidding will enable you to win the cards you lack. Just find out the best way to manage your gold mine !
Entertaining, special cards will help you to slow down your opponents' progress or to speed up your own.
Simple, suitable from age 9, each game lasts between 15 and 30 minutes.

(From the publisher's site)

From prehistory to the invention of writing!

Uruk: Mesopotamian town, the cradle of writing! 
Just over 5000 years ago, when the first game of chance ever discovered was already being played, a major event in the history of the world took place: man learnt to write!

Uruk: The card game combining the story and adventure of writing!
Easy, work in stages towards your ultimate goal: the invention of writing.
Fun, play special cards to slow down your opponent's progress or speed up your own.
Simple, suitable from 6 to 77+ years of age, each game lasts between 10 and 20 minutes.

A simple and fast boardgame contained within a box. One page of rules, fantastic graphics on the map, 20 plastic miniatures, dice, and hours of simple war gaming fun.

This game is not designed to simulate, it is a game. Fathers and sons, fathers and daughters, and even mothers with children will love the simplicity and speed (most games last less than 30 minutes). Old school gamers will also love it as a quick fix game.

It is 1940. Players choose the Allies or the Axis to play. The board has preset armies for both side that begin on the board. A game last 15 turns unless a clear winner before then. Some turns have preset first phase players, some the players dice for initiative. On those turns player get to go first automatically, they also receive reinforcements. Essentially, the allies must hold out until mid-game or they are going to loose. The Germans must win quick, or the allies will eventually overwhelm them. Hey! Just like the real war...

The game uses very simple mechanics for movement and combat, and it is in no way a simulation. The idea is to provide a "beer and pretzels" game for those who don't have time to play a more involved wargame.

The concept behind the Battle Box series is simple and fun: Play when you can. The game is perfect for introducing young would be generals to wargaming, as even as early as 10 years old the rules and concepts are easily grasped.

Available at www.flamingmonkeygames.com

Each player has four pieces (cups) with a ball (marble) in one of the pieces. Each player's pieces start in the row nearest to the player. Players maneuver their four pieces diagonally toward the other side of the board, backtracking when necessary, and passing the marble from one piece to another until one of their pieces with their marble reaches the opponent's starting row, winning the game.

Blåfjell (Blue Mountain) is a spin-off from the extremely popular children's television show "Jul i Blåfjell" (Christmas at Blue Mountain) by NRK (Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation).

Players collect red and blue hats and try to reach Blåfjell before the dusk comes.

A rugby simulation board game that involves luck, and physical skill.

Players are able to move with the ball, pass, tackle and kick. Cards can be tactically used when in possession of the ball. All kicks are physically taken by propelling the ball with the plastic player. The game includes posts through which the ball must be kicked to score conversions or penalties.
Lippy the Lion Flips Game is based on the Hanna-Barbera (1962) cartoon of the same name. With Hardy Har Har the Laughless Hyena this is a simple follow the path roll and move game.

The Gumps at the Seashore is a simple roll and move game from the 1930's.

Box has nice graphics with Andy, Chester and Min, signed by cartoonist Sidney Smith.

name.value: Captain Kangaroo Let's Build a House

item.description: Spin and move game based on the television show Captain Kangaroo. Object of game: 1) First player uses the spinner and if the hand points to blue half, he may choose any tool and place it on his tool board. He may also take a piece of his puzzle of the same color as his tool board. 2) If spinner points to the blank or the yellow half of circle, it becomes next player’s turn. 3) First player to have all six tools and all parts of his house together wins the game.

Down the Hatch published by Cadaco-Ellis in 1943 is a "fast action marble game". Marbles are dropped into a tower like structure and eventually come out the bottom and then land on different spots on the game board. Those spots score different amounts of points.

The Champion Game of Baseball was published by the Proctor Amusement Company of North Cambridge, Massachusetts in 1889. It consists of a baseball field printed on the bottom of the box with a metal spinner in the middle, a rules sheet, and an envelope with nine blue and nine red cardboard disks.

There is not a lot of strategy in this early game - each team uses the spinner on its turn to bat. Most of the results are either outs or hits (spaces for single, double, triple and home run), but there also are spaces for strikes, balls and base on balls. It is therefore possible but unlikely to get three strikes or four balls. There is one space for a foul ball, and any spinner stopping on a line is considered a foul as well.

The one strategic option open to the batting team is whether to have base runners try to steal. In this event, the stealing team spins again, but uses an outer ring where the results are divided between "out", "safe" or "sacrifice" (where the runner advances but the current batter is out). An out result always picks off the lead runner.

There were a few more real life dictators in the world when this game was published in 1939. Very little information can be found about this board game.

Update - The game comes with many lead minatures (8 Aviators representing each player, 12 submarines, 8 Battleships and 16 aeroplanes). Definitely the king of game play pieces by weight alone. The map contains a circle of spaces surrounded by 3 territories which hold the game's key resources- Manchukuo (Iron), Dutch East Indies (Oil) & Ukraine (Wheat). The game play spaces have actions (like collect $4 million or capture enemy plane) or consequences (sub sunk) and even political events (revolt, coup or treaty - which are separate cards).

The center of the board represents the armament factory and all the minatures begin there to be bought by the player as they build up their forces. The players move around the circle by the roll of the dice collecting and losing money, armaments and political cards to be used in the game. The goal of the game is to collect military forces so that you can control the 3 territories (1 at a time or if you are strong enough, all at once). The players move military units into and out of the territories on their turns, conquering weaker opponents (and taking their units). If you have the required military units in the territory and you have earned a propaganda card (by landing on the right space) you gain the resource of that territory. Having all 3 resources wins the game.

It is believed that even copies in very good to very fine condition, used copies that may even be missing a part or two, were worth between $500 and $600 as recently as the year 2000. For those looking for this game, it comes in a long red box with the word "Dictator" written across the front in red lettering on top of a curved white stripe.

name.value: Donny & Marie Osmond TV Show Game

item.description: In this game for children Ages 7 - 12, players pretend to be television performers on tour. The object of the game is to win the top star award reaching the finish line with at least $10,000.

This "Follow The Leader game" includes a game board with a cartoon-like village scene, 16 Nothin cards with a boy's unhappy face, 14 Double cards with a boy's smiling face, 2 Triple cards with a boy's excited face, 4 plastic boy figures, and a white die. The cards are used to increase the die roll movement or to give the player nothin'.

Falaise Pocket is based on the World War II battle in France occurring in August, 1944, between the Allies and the Germans, following the D-Day invasion. The object of the game for the Germans is to evacuate as many units as out of the pocket as possible. The Allied goal is to prevent this.

Published in Panzer Digest #1, Falaise Pocket is a DTP game.

Advanced Salvo! is a simple World War II naval wargame consisting of rules, game tables, ship counters and markers. It plays very much the same way as the Salvo! game published by Minden Games, except with further refinements. The game may be played solitaire or by two players and the rules are worded for solitaire play. Advanced Salvo! is fully compatible with the standard Salvo! game.

Published in Panzer Digest #1. Advanced Salvo! is a DTP game.

Expands:


 Salvo!


Expanded by:


 Mediterranean Salvo!
 Pacific Salvo!

Salvo! is a solitaire WW2 naval wargame consisting of rules, game tables and several ship counters. Three d6 dice, paper and pencil are also required and not included in the game.

Salvo! is a "postcard" game published by Minden Games.

Expanded by:

 Advanced Salvo! 1939-1941
 Mediterranean Salvo!
 Pacific Salvo!
 Great War Salvo!
 Salvo! River Plate

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
You find yourself part of a Penal Battalion somewhere on the Eastern Front during World War II. Your unit's current job is clearing minefields. You can't exactly refuse to work, but there's no need to rush headlong into eager compliance with every order, is there?

Penal Battalion is a very simple solitaire card game of strategy. The object is straightforward: if you go BOOM, you lose. If you survive through the whole deck, you "win," and get to do the same thing tomorrow...

Published in Panzer Digest #1. Requires a standard deck of 52 playing cards and several markers (pennies, buttons, etc).

Longstreet's Disaster is a simple, solitaire game depicting Pickett's Charge during the Battle of Gettysburg on July 3, 1863. The player controls the Confederate (CSA) side, while the game system plays the Union (US) side.

Published in Panzer Digest #1. Longstreet's Disaster is a DTP game.

In Bokstavleken (The Letter game), a letter and a topic is revealed. The first player to name an object in this topic gets the letter.

Is quite similar to Ordjakten, but this game is restricting words to begin with a specific letter, and comes without a timer.

In Bondegårdsspillet (The Farm Game), the players compete to fill their board with farm animals. A spinner decides which animal the player is allowed to take from the supply. With the Farmer, the player can decide freely, but with the Tractor, no animal can be taken.

This game is based on Aussie Rules Football. Rolls of the dice dictate the direction that the ball heads in. A certain number of dice rolls are equivalent to each quarter of the game. At the end of four quarters the person or team with the highest score wins.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Bursdagsfesten (The Birthday Party) is a children's game in the theme of Winnie the Pooh, where the players must find seven friends of Pooh and the honey he will serve in the party.

On the board, there are squares with friends of Pooh. When landing on such a square, the player must find the friend amongst the hidden markers. If the marker does not match, it is put back in the pile.

Den lille Havfruen (The little Mermaid) is a Disney themed children's game where the players compete to reach the castle of Prince Eric while holding the card with the Mermaid's voice.

The players move to the shipwreck and collect cards, and then to the sea witch to get transformed. After becoming a women, the player must avoid the traps of the castle to get to the Prince.

Den lille røde traktoren (The little red tractor) is based on a BBC children's television show, where the players must direct three different tractors ("Den lille røde traktoren", "Blå Boss" and "Treske") to specific squares.

Each turn, the die is thrown and a goal square is revealed from a card. The player must choose one of the tractors depicted on the card and try to move it to the square on the card, using the exact movement of the die. If the player is successful, the player wins the card.

Dinosaurspelet (The Dinosaur Game) is set in the theme of Disney's "Dinosaur", where the players control Aladar and his friends to find his native breeding grounds. Chased by raptors the players might have to sacrifice some of Aladar's friends to reach home.

Contents:

- Game Board
- 83 cardboard pieces
- 4 playing pieces with plastic feet 
- Die

The object of the game is to be the first player to feed all your food tokens to Ralph. On each turn players roll a die and must feed him certain food. A numbered roll (1, 2, or 3) indicates the number of food pieces that he must swallow. If a player rolls "Stuff," he or she can attempt to feed him as much food as the player wants to attempt. If he regurgitates the food, the player must keep it which may include some that the player did not feed him. (Ralph is also a common expression for vomiting.)

Dietary note: "Ralph has a sensitive stomach! Please don't feed him anything except the special cardboard food enclosed."

From the publisher:

“Play ball!” Now your whole family can experience America's greatest pastime with Front Porch Classics Baseball . A tribute to the grand old ballparks of yesteryear, this exquisitely detailed pinball-style Rec Room game provides fun on a grand scale. Forget the batteries and gather round. Players young and old launch the pinball and swing the bat to hit singles, doubles, triples and homeruns. Record each batter's performance on actual scorecards, while keeping track of runs scored on the stadium scoreboard.

King of the Hill is a version of the children's game of War, with a strategic aspect added. Just like the parent game, it uses ordinary playing cards. Players get to choose the cards to be played and the reward for winning. A separate reserve of cards to break ties adds to the strategy. Win as many cards as you can, but remember, only the player who wins the last battle can be King of the Hill!
Score more points than your opponent by climbing your largest dice as far up the mountain as you can before the game ends.

Bosconian-D is a print-and-play solo dice wargame based on the old Namco arcade game of the same name.

In up to 36 sectors of space destroy your enemy's bases, or encounter various enemies. Destroy them or they will damage your ship.

Can you eliminate all enemy bases before your ship is sustains 100 points of damage?

All you need are the rules, dice and a pencil. Counters for your ship and the enemy bases, a simple grid board, and an encounter die is provided.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
From the manual:

"Outsmart other corporate wheeler dealers and avoid bankruptcy! Capitalize on the ups and downs of a fluctuating economy! Climb the corporate ladder and become a megabucks big shot!"

Players roll and move around the game board buying chairs in various companies or triggering a range of events such as Depression, Inflation, Boom and Bust. Interestingly, the game time is set at the beginning. The winner is the player with the most cash on hand combined with the current value of the various chairs of each company they're on.

It's an Australian game and most of the companies are either Australian or multi-national.

Creepy crawly – what's that crawling over there? It's the colorful caterpillars who are scuttling out from under the leaves bit by bit! Whoever is lucky enough with the dice in Caterpillar Dice to make her own complete caterpillar wins!

link.value: HABA Game in a Tin series

item.description:
There are five suits in this game: The 12 royal cards (J, Q, K) of all four traditional suits make one suit; they don’t count for their normal suits. The remaining cards in the other suits (A to 10 in spades, hearts, clubs, and diamonds) make the other four suits.

If you’re starting a hand, you must play one or more cards of only one suit (S, H, C, D, royals). Play passes to your left.

When play passes to you, you may pass or play. If you pass, play passes to your left. If you play, you must play a homogeneous set of cards that beats what was most recently played. The rank of the card you play is irrelevant, but the number of cards you play and their suit is relevant.

Suit Ranking:
Hearts beat spades and clubs. Clubs beat hearts and diamonds. Diamonds beat clubs and royals. Royals beat diamonds and spades. Spades beat royals and hearts.

If the most recent play was one heart, you can play one club, or one spade, or two hearts. You can not play more than what you need to beat what was played; you can’t play three or more hearts or two or more clubs or spades.

Short play example:
Alice starts a hand by playing two clubs. Bob plays three clubs. Cathy passes. Dan plays three diamonds. Alice passes. Bob passes. Cathy plays three royals. Dan plays four royals. Alice plays four diamonds. Bob plays four clubs. Cathy plays four hearts. Dan passes. Alice plays five hearts. Bob, Cathy, and Dan all pass and Alice takes the hand.

If play passes back to you and you were the last player to play, you get the ewe totem and all of the cards played go face-down into your Wool Pile. You get a one-point bonus to your score. The hand is over.

If all players have cards left in hand, the player to the left of the player with the ewe starts the next hand. If at least one player is out of cards the round is over. If you have cards in hand at the end of a round, you lose one point for every card in your hand. If you have the ewe at the end of a round, you get a two-point bonus to your score.

If the round is over, count the number of cards in your Wool Pile and have the scorekeeper add that to your score. If one or more players have 100 points or more, the game is over. If the game is not over, collect and shuffle all of the cards.

If you have the ewe at the end of the game, you get a 5-point bonus to your score.

From the Publishers Website:
uPSet is a thrilling and unpredictable combination of chance and strategy where one throw of the dice or one play of a card can turn the game around and the winner of the game is in doubt until the very last second.
Using dice, cards, an interactive scoresheet and poker-style chips (uPcentS), uPSet takes only a few minutes to learn but every game is a different roller-coaster ride of fun and excitement. uPSet strikes that perfect balance between rewarding skilled and strategic play and introducing the element of luck to make sure that everyone has a chance to win and victory is never a sure thing.

Inspired by games played in Labrador fishing villages, Upset includes specialty dice, cards, chips, and interactive scorecards that shape play by determining who gets the cards and when. The object of the game is to score points with the dice (10,000 to win) and strategically use the Upset cards to beat your opponent. Players strategize not only on how and when they play their cards, but also how to get or avoid getting the cards. However, the special dice contain letters as well as numbers and if someone rolls the word "Upset," then everyone else, no matter how close they are to winning, must restart from scratch.

Home Page: http://www.playupset.com/

This is the first known game designed by Spanish gamer Victor Melo.

Winner of the "I Board Games Creation Contest" at Granollers (Barcelona), El Mercado Azteca (The aztec market) is becoming popular inside Spanish gamers' community. The contest is the result of the impulse and work of a great well known Spanish designer: Oriol Comas i Coma.

The game is almost a pure German Game:

 Small and easy set of rules
 Fast games
 Attractive theme not too present in the game flow




It has also an easy Print & Play prototype that you can play just by printing some counters and using some extra components from other games or even from your kitchen (beans,...).

About the theme:
The game tries to represent the great pre-Columbian market of Tlatelolco (Mexico). The player is a merchant trying to get goods (4 different types) from the sellers while trying to increase their value. To increase your chances of buying you'll need to spend your influence points to adapt the market to your needs. The board is modular and changes every turn. The players can move the board pieces, this being an important part of the strategy.

This game is winner of the 2007 Concurs Ciutat de Granollers de creaciÃ³ de jocs.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The object of this abstract game is to place five tokens of one color in a row in any direction on a special 12 by 12 game board grid or to force your opponent into three "traps" -- the twenty red squares on the game board.

The four-player version of the game involves team play while the three-player version involves one player alternatively playing against the other two.

100 points for completing a five-in-a-row formation.

Other bonus scoring include the following:
 100 points for completing a five-in-a-row formation with 10 tokens or less.
 50 points for completing a five-in-a-row formation within the pink square.
 50 points for forcing your opponent into 3 traps.
 20 points for forcing your opponent into 2 traps.
 10 points for forcing your opponent into 1 trap.

This game was manufactured by Wales Games Systems, Inc., a division of Wales-Strippit Corporation in North Tonawanda, New York, USA. It was later slightly modified to fit in with the western theme of Wales Game Systems' other games, having a cowboy hat added to the drawing of Joe and becoming "Tagalong Cowboy Joe," a "64-32 Ranch Game."

This abstract game consists of equilateral triangular tiles. During the initial setup, each tile must touch at least one other triangle already placed on the table, and then one of the players pawns is placed on the center of the triangle tile. The second phase involves pawn displacement and hunting. The object of the game is to capture all the pawns of the player on your left or to insulate them by moving or eliminating the tiles.

The playing time has been listed as either 30 or 60 minutes. This may depend upon the number of players.

Awards:

 1990 - Concours International de CrÃ©ateurs de Jeux de SociÃ©tÃ© de Boulogne-Billancourt Winner of the Golden goblet.

The object of this vintage abstract game is to make a straight line of four pieces or a diamond shape. The game comes with a gridded game board, two sets of colored pegs, and some score sheets. The complete instructions are on the inside of the outer lid.

Played on 7x7. The object is to get a line of four orthogonally, or diagonally. Also a box of four "on and angle" with the center square empty counts as a win.

Premiered at Essen 2000.

Intended for Ages 4 and up

Equipment: 26 card pairs displaying food, 1 pair of family cards, 1 tooth, 1 toothbrush, 1 bacterium, 1 Decoder, tooth cleaning glossary

In the first game children gather together pairs of food cards and take turns stating whether the food is healthy for teeth or contains too much sugar. By training the decoder on a red point on the cards, they can determine whether they are correct or not.

The second game is played more like traditional Memory, but in addition, after claiming the pair the child must state whether the food is tooth-friendly or not.

The family cards are always taken automatically without further tests being applied.

Tooth, toothbrush and bacterium are used to indicate the various food statuses.

Received 2 out of a possible 6 dice pips at Spielphase, due to ambiguities of the cards.

(Translated from the publisher's site in Norwegian)

KUnnskap (KU=cow) på boks is a trivia and strategy game for the whole family! The game consists of general trivia questions, riddles and picture puzzles at two levels: one for mature cows (more or less adults) - and one suited for 10 year olds (playful calves) and up.

Strategy? Well, it is all about getting the largest field. The player with the largest field, wins the game! One has to use strategic cunning by colour mounds. The point is to hinder the other players in expanding their fields, while every player tries to make their own fields as large and bountiful as possible. The players amass points by solving the exercises.

På forhånd bestemmer man seg for å spille med en stor beitemark (+ 1 time) eller en mindre hvis man ønsker et raskere spill (+ 30 minutter). Spillet egner seg for 2 til 4 spillere eller lag.

Illustrasjonene er elleville og humoristiske og vil glede både store og små!

In advance the players decide either to play for a large field (60+ minutes) or a smaller one if they wish a quicker game (30+ minutes). The game is suitable for 2 to 4 players or teams.

The illustrations are hilarious and humouristic, and will please young and old!

Mooohh!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
(Translated from publisher's site in Norwegian)
How much do you actually know about the USA? About the USA's culture, geography, showbiz and famous people? In this game you really get to test your knowledge - and you are guaranteed to learn something new.

The game is divided into three categories; Stars and Stripes (with geography, culture and history) - where all the states are present, Showtime USA (sports and entertainment) - where Entertainer includes miming tasks to be solved on time. Every card of questions has a picture and a question relating to it. All the pictures depict the USA, and make the game a wonderful visual experience! The content in the Star and Stripes category is based on the high school curriculum. The game has been been developed by the experienced educational book writer Clara Amland.

New Gladiators - Retiarius; Amazon; Bestiarius; Criminal; Lion. New rules. A complete Campaign system. Colour-coded dice.

New Stuff. More Stuff.

A complete game in it's own right and also totally compatible with Ludus Gladiatorius 1.

Gladiators supplied painted. Play sheet included. Everything required to play is supplied, including a pouch to randomly pick counters from..!

This is the sequel of Ludus Gladiatorius. Integrates with it, but it's also completely playable stand-alone.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: En for alle, alle for en

item.description:
En for alle, alle for en (One for all, all for one) is a cooperative childrens game where the players cooperatively move a team of mountain climbers.

The climbers are connected with a rope such that there cannot be more than two spaces between one and the next. The moves can be divided freely among all climbers.

All players win if the climbers reach the summit before the sun sets. Else they all lose.

Contents:

- Game board
- 4 mountain climbers with rope
- One sun
- 26 action cards
- One die

In Donald Ducks Bondegårdspill (Donald Duck's Farm Game), the players play Hewey, Dewey and Louis (and perhaps Phooey ?) on Grandma Duck's farm trying to collect a complete set of apples, milk, corn and egg.

Contents:

- Game board
- Wheel with needle to attach to the board
- Four playing pieces with plastic feet
- 16 pieces of apples, milk, corn and egg
- One special die

From the back of the box: Kanji symbols are an ancient Chinese method of writing that was introduced to Japan almost 2,000 years ago. Kanji symbols are visual representations of words, word fragments or entire ideas. While there are as many as 50,000 Kanji in existence, Japanese people use only about 2,000 today.

For 2 to 4 players ages 5 and up.

THE OBJECT: To be the player to collect the most points by the end of the round.

HOW TO PLAY: The Kanji game has three levels of play. Set up the double-sided playing board according to the level of play you choose. Divide the 176 cards into four card groups: GO, 1-2-3, Kanji and Dot. Give the arrow a spin and let the race begin.

A card is drawn and players must think and react quickly as they learn how to speak, read and visualize Kanji symbols. The first player to find the card's exact match on the playing board (matching color and symbol) and to place his or her pawn on the match wins the card. Did you draw a Kanji Samurai card? Now you must draw the Kanji symbol, the final step in putting it all together!

Whoever has the most points at the end of the round wins that game! Sounds easy? Think again!

What are you learning? Not only are players learning the elements of a foreign language, they are also building the skills necessary to improve mathematics, memory, concentration and visual relationships while actively being motivated to think, respond and learn!

In Bursdagsspillet (The Birthday Game), the players are invited to Donald Duck's birthday party and must play a round of the Hat Game before proceeding to the cake.

The players throw the dice to determine which color of the hat to move. A hat can be put on top of one single other hat, be freed on special balloon squares, or being swapped if the special die shows the party hat. When a single or double hat passes the finish line, one point goes to the player playing the color of the hat on the top.

Contents:

- Game board
- 16 hats in 4 colors
- 1 regular die
- 1 special die with colors

In Prinsessespillet (The Princess Game), the players try to get rid of their princess chips. One playing piece is moved around the board and determines if the active player gets to wear the tiara, loses one princess chip, or gives chips to another player.

When a player loses her/his last chip, he/she either wins (if having the tiara on their head), or loses (if not).

Contents:

- Game Board
- Tiara
- One playing piece
- 30 princess chips

In Fischer Price Bondegårdspillet (Fischer Price's The Farm Game), players compete to collect all of their food pieces. Each player controls one animal and simultaneously the farmer and his or her animal. If the farmer is adjacent to the animal (they move in separate zones of the board), the animal is fed.

The first player to get ten food pieces wins.

Contents:

Game board
Farmer figure
Four animal figures
40 food pieces
One colored die

'Fargerally' (Color Rally) is a children's game consisting of two phases:

Phase 1: Collect six meeples of different colors and place in your racing car.
Phase 2: Race your car to the finish line.

The dice are used both to collect meeples and to advance the cars to the next square of matching colors.

Contents:

- Game board
- Four wooden racing cars
- 24 meeples in six colors
- Two colored dice

Form & Gjett (Mould and Guess) is a unique game where two and two players team up. Each round, one of the players of the team chooses a timed task (Foot in the air, jump like a rabbit, swing your arms etc) and tries to perform that action as long as possible, while the other player moulds whatever is depicted on the figure card. The first team to fill their sheet wins.

Contents:

Six time sheets with six tasks each
54 figure cards
Two boxes of moulding clay

In Først og Sist (First and last), players try to find words starting with a given letter and ending with any letter shown on the game board. If a player successfully finds a word, he or she takes the first letter, and moves the last letter to the top of the game board, becoming the starting letter of the next word, which the next player must find.

If a player cannot find a word, the starting letter is turned around, only to become a new letter, or a joker.

Contents:

Game board
48 letters

A children's game which can be played two different ways. In both games 12 tiles are set in a square and each player places their cow on the first square. The objective is to get your cow around the square. The colored milk bottles are set up in the middle of the square.

In the version called The Cow Goes Moo, each player takes turns rolling the color die and trying to knock over up to five bottles, but not more than five or they will lose their turn. The player gets to move their cow one space for each fallen bottle which matches the color rolled on the die.

In the Big Cow Poker version, before each roll, every player secretly chooses a color card. The roller knocks down up to five milk bottles and each player gets to move a number of spaces equal to the number of fallen bottles which match their card.

Box Description:

OFF TO NEVERLAND WITH PETER PAN! The Pirates, Indians, Tinkerbell and Captain Hook (Boo!) are all here. A delightful board game for 2, 3, 4 players Ages 6 and up.

Additional Notes:

Simple spin and move pawn type game for kids to relive the story of Peter Pan.

In Witch - Stjernespillet (Witch - The star game), players compete to reach the center of the playing field.

The sign cards tell whether the player should move forwards or backwards, and the number cards is played by the player to say how many squares she or he wants to move.

If a heart square is reached, the player must see if his or her sign of the zodiac matches one on the topmost dream boy card.

Contents:

Game board
38 sign cards
38 number cards
12 sign of the zodiac cards
12 dream boy cards
Four pawns

In this game, players place bets on whether the current player is able to find a word in the specific topic using all of the given letters. Each player may bet between one and three chips on either yes or no. (The current player bets last and must bet yes).

The spinner is used to determine how many letters is picked each time.

The first player to acquire all chips in his or her color wins.

Contents:

Game board
110 topic cards
44 letter cards
Six yes cards
Six no cards
144 chips in six colors
One spinner
One hour glass

In Gulljakten (The Goldrush) is a children's game where the players use a scale to measure the amount of gold they dig.

When landing on a green square, the player gains gold, and when landing on a red square, the player must purchase food, drinks or being robbed.

All actions use the scales to weigh the token on the square, and balance them with an appropriate number of lumps of gold on the other side.

Contents:

Game board
Four gold diggers with plastic feet
Four digging tools
One die
Lumps of gold
One pair of scales

Junior Gruble is a children's edition of Gruble, with easier rules and the players don't need to be able to write.

The youngest player chooses one subject on the game board and places the marker there. He or she then throws all four dice, and the first to find a word in the topic beginning with any of the four letters can put one of his chips in the same square.

The first player to place all four chips in his or her color wins.

Contents:

Game board
Four dice with letters
16 chips in four colors
One black marker

Three childrens games can be played with this set of letter stamps, "ghost" tins and "ghost" word cards.

In Little Ghostly Alphabet the objective is to stamp two words. The stamps are put in the tins. Then each player gets a ghost card with a word on it. The words are in multiple languages, including English. Each turn a player selects a tin, then stamps any letters which are in their word. The letters must be stamped in order.

The Word Searchers is a variation on Hangman, using the stamps.

In G as Ghost, the stamps are again put in the tins. Each player chooses a tin, then uses a stamp inside to either start a new word or extend a word that is already started. Players must announce the word they are thinking of. Other players can either stamp the letters in that word or switch to another word as long as the letters already stamped match the new word. Only three words can be started at a time. The game ends after five words are completed.

A game in the series of Norwegian Geni trivia games, released in the event of Norway's 100th anniversary. The rules are equivalent to the original Geni, but this game only has four categories, namely Norway and the world, Sports and Entertainment, This changed us, and Norwegian history. To win the game, the player must correctly answer a by the players chosen number of questions from one card correctly.

Contents:

Game board
Six playing pieces
24 Geni-pieces
250 cards with 1000 questions

Junior Geni is a children's edition of the very popular Norwegian trivia game Geni, with simplified rules and different question categories.

The goal of this game is to answer one question correctly from each of the four categories, and then answer questions from two given categories, moving to the center of the board. The first player to reach the center is the winner.

Originally released in 1988, the game has been re-released with new questions and categories in 1995, 1998, 2000, 2003 and 2007.

Each game typically contains 250 cards, all with questions from all four categories, including 'Books and music', 'Our world', 'Nature', 'Entertainment', 'Science', varying from the different editions.

Before starting the actual game of Gambler Casino, all players must invent three prizes and write them on their note pad. (The rules suggest "Anything from a chocolate to an orange, or free baby sitting".) The players use the roulette to claim the prizes.

The prizes are won if the ball stops on a '3' or '5', and the player correctly guesses a 'higher' or 'lower' value on 3 (or 5) successive cards. The player may choose to do double or nothing with this prize. When there are only prizes of a single color left, the player with the most prizes is named "Casino Gambler of the Year" and gets the rest of the prizes.

Contents:

Game board
Playing cards
Roulette
Six note pads in different colors

From the front of the box:

"Triolo is a game of skill for two players. You begin with twelve counters each and take turns to place them around the network of lines on the Triolo board. Maneuver three of your counters into a straight line and you've formed a Triolo. Each time you outwit your opponent and form a Triolo you take one of his counters from the board. Form enough Triolos to remove all his counters and you win the game."

A game for all ages from 8 to 99 years.

This is a game that was mailed exclusively to Disney Rewards Visa Card members. The game is for preschoolers and is based on the new Playhouse Disney show.
You can be one of four Super Sleuths in the game: Pooh, Tigger, Darby or Buster. On your turn you spin the spinner and advance to that color. You will follow any directions on that square. The player to get around the 21 squares first is the declared the winner and told he solved the mystery.

Made by LDS (Latter Day Saints) Game Factory in Placerville, CA. I don't have the instructions, but it looks as though players go around the board -- and off into little side trips like Talents, Leisure, Career, Church. Family and Education -- to gather Blessings but to avoid Trespasses. According to the score sheets, you tally each, plus add the number of side trips made to the Blessing column and it looks like the highest Blessing score wins.

Knowledge cards get you Blessings or Trespasses. Free Agency cards quote verses from LDS scripture. Corner spaces are significant: Go on a Mission or to the Tree of Life; these are the good squares. The bad ones are Temptation and Sin City. It looks like Sin City is like Monopoly's Jail square. You must roll to get out and the longer it takes, the more Trespasses you get.

(Not to be confused with Hestespillet (1996), also by Damm / Egmont.)

Hestespillet (The Horse Game) is a children's racing game, where the players play gallop cards to advance in the course. Players must also play jump cards to overcome the hurdles. There are also some special cards to push or swap the hurdles.

Contents:

Game board
36 move cards
4 pawns with plastic feet
20 hurdles

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Hjulene på bussen (The Wheels on the Bus) is a children's game where the players try and get all their pawns on the bus that goes around the game board.

Each turn, the player first throw the die and moves the bus. If the bus gets to a bus stop with pawns on, it stops and the pawns are entering the bus (removed from the game). Then the player throws the die once more and moves one of his or her pawns.

The first player to get all pawns on the bus, wins.

Contents:

16 pawns in four colors
One bus pawn with plastic foot
One die

Honningspillet (The Honey Game) is a Winnie the Pooh-themed children's game.

All playing pieces are mixed before the game starts, and the only way to find out who controls which piece is to move to a bee square and look at the sticker at the bottom of the honey pot. The players must then remember the colors and move their own pots towards the goal.

The first player to get all his or her honey pots to the goal is the winner.

Contents:

Game board
12 honey pot pieces with plastic feet
12 stickers
1 die
